description: From Latin stypticus, from Ancient Greek στυπτικός (stuptikós), from στύφειν (stúphein, “to contract”).

adjectives.description: styptic (comparative more styptic, superlative most styptic)

entries.meaning: Bringing about contraction of tissues; harsh, raw, austere.
examples: Boyles turns to look over his shoulder, squinting into the styptic sun, and then flags a hand over his head.
The growth on top was a scrubby plant, unknown anywhere else on Malta, which was believed to have styptic qualities – it could staunch bleeding when packed on top of a wound […].

entries.meaning: A substance used for styptic results.
examples: Knowledge of puffball's use as a styptic and for hemorrhoids reached Bass through the popular tradition.
